beta-1 -- > 3-D-glucans represent a pathogen - associated molecular pattern and are able to modify biological responses .

Employing a comprehensive methodological approach , the aim of our in vitro study was to elucidate novel molecular and cellular mechanisms of human peripheral blood immune cells mediated by a fungal beta-1 -- > 3-D-glucan , i.e . glucan phosphate , in the presence of lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) or <extra_id_0> toxic shock syndrome toxin 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

Despite an activation of nuclear factor ( NF ) kappaB , <extra_id_0> NFinterleukin(IL)-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> NFAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> similar to LPS or <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , we observed no significant production of <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> interferon gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induced by glucan phosphate .

Glucan phosphate - treated leukocytes induced a substantial amount of <extra_id_0> IL-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( peak at 18 h : 5000 pg / ml ) , likely due to binding of NFkappaB to a consensus site in the <extra_id_0> IL-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

An increase in <extra_id_0> IL-1receptor antagonist <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) production ( peak at 24 h : 12000 pg / ml ) by glucan phosphate - treated cells positively correlated with <extra_id_0> IL-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> levels .

Glucan phosphate induced significant binding to a known NFIL-6 site and a new NFAT site within the <extra_id_0> IL-1RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter , which was confirmed by inhibition experiments .

When applied in combination with either LPS or <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at the same time points , we detected that glucan phosphate elevated the LPS - and the <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced DNA binding of NFkappaB , <extra_id_0> NFIL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> NFAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , leading to a synergistic increase of <extra_id_0> IL-1RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Further , glucan phosphate modulated the <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced inflammatory response via reduction of <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

As a consequence , glucan phosphate shifted the <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> IL-1RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ratio towards an anti-inflammatory phenotype .

Subsequently , glucan phosphate decreased the <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced , <extra_id_0> IL-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent production of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Thus , beta-1 -- > 3-D-glucans may induce beneficial effects in the presence of pro-inflammatory responses , downstream of receptor binding and signaling by switching a pro - to an anti-inflammatory <extra_id_0> IL-1RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated reaction .
Our results also offer new insights into the complex regulation of the <extra_id_0> IL-1RA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , which can be modulated by a beta-1 -- > 3-D-glucan .
